title: Prohibiting retirement agreements between teachers accused of misconduct and school districts
summary: Prohibits retirement agreements between teachers accused of misconduct and school districts unless such agreement includes the voluntary surrender of such teacher's license or teaching certificate.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1661

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the education law, in relation to prohibiting retirement
agreements between teachers accused of misconduct and school districts

PURPOSE:
To forbid retirement agreements between school districts and teachers
accused of misconduct unless the agreement includes the voluntary
surrender of teaching certificate or license.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
The Education law is amended by adding a new section 301l-a that
prohibits retirement agreements between teachers accused of
misconduct and school districts unless the teacher in question agrees
to surrender his/her teaching license or teaching certificate.
Provides for return of the teaching license/certificate upon
exoneration from the allegations of misconduct.

JUSTIFICATION:
Recently the New York State Commission on Investigation investigated
the case of a teacher in Putnam County accused of molesting one
student and acting inappropriately towards other students in the same
school. The school district in question entered into an agreement
with the accused teacher that allowed the teacher to retire and in
exchange the school district agreed not to bring disciplinary
charges. The Commission on Investigation found that "The Commission
finds that the separation agreement reached between the School
District and the Teacher is not unusual. Allowing a teacher accused
of misconduct to retire is often the end result of a school
district's cost-benefit analysis, which invariably includes an
analysis of the strength of the evidence:" Retirement agreements
between teachers accused of misconduct and school districts "make the
problem go away" for the districts but they leave the teachers in
question in good educational standing. Such teachers can use their
intact teaching credentials to secure employment in other districts
throughout New York State. Because of the voluntary retirement
agreement, background checks by the potential new employers will not
show any criminal history. Rather, they will show "retired from
school district X".
Although allegations are not proven facts, we in the Legislature
must do everything possible to ensure that students learn in a safe
environment with trustworthy staff. We cannot allow potential
predators leeway to continue to prey on students at new school systems.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
